reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my opinion is is the best co-op shooter to come out in many years.

The formula is simple. You are a marine tasked with downloading information from various datacores scattered around the  claustrophic confines of an alien infested spaceship. After you have collected all the datacores you then have to shut down the cooling nodes on the reactor and then evacuate safely to the start point before the reactor explodes.

What makes the above formula so successful, especially in co-op, is the tension, danger and the various means by which players can approach a level.

The aliens are dangerous. The aliens are numerous. The aliens will kill you if they get close. Thus this game brings a lot of tension because death is always moments away.

This game has captured perfectly the atmosphere that was present in a 1995 3DO game called Space Hulk: Vengeance of the Blood Angels.  The ship ambience sounds bleak and forboding, the aliens breaking through doorways always sounds menacing, the sound of distant gunfire from a team mate reminds you trouble is not so far away.


The game is very customisable allowing players to increase the difficulty level to that which is nigh on impossible. Players can also tone down the muzzle flash and field of view effects which can be a bit overbearing in my opintion (I turn them all the way down). I also turn the action music off as it gets very repetitive after awhile.


The levels are procedurally generated so there is always a new and challenging permutation to play. Players can also enter specific seeds so that common levels can be practiced, shared and ultimately conquered.

Some of the best moments I have had with this game is with a group on Mumble (voip software) forming a plan on the map screen prior to entering the fray. We then enter the fray and very often fail the mission only to tweak our strategy or take a slightly different approach until we eventually succeed. This is where the game really shines in my opinion.

Summary

Pros - Atmospheric, Difficult and Challenging, Strategic, Endless Level Permutations, Frantic.

Cons - Multiplayer is still in its infancy and it can be very laggy if playing with someone across the pond (ie. Europe to US etc.). Some might say the graphics are a con due to the game not looking like Crysis but graphics do not necessarily make a game. The graphics are perfectly sufficient for what we get and do not detract one iota from the fun factor.


If you want to experience the movie Aliens, experience the game Aliens versus Predator, or experience a game like SPace Hulk: Vengeance of the Blood Angels then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A proper Aliens game has finally been made and its name is Space Beast Terror Fright. You and your friends are Marines who are given the simple objective of recovering all data cores on a ship and then overload that ships reactors and escaping back to your shuttle before the ship blows. There's just one problem, the ship is completely infested with Aliens.

Ever since I was a kid I have always wanted a game like this. A game where there is no massive story you are just a marine with a job to do on various different locations involving Aliens. This game is essentially Aliens meets Space Hulk vengeance of the blood angels only instead of AI companions it is either just you or 3 of your friends.

You download datacores and all datacores have a chance of giving you an upgrade of which all have their own different levels. For example your basic motion tracker lvl 1 only tells you if something is moving near you. Lvl 2 motion tracker gives you short range blips indicating where enemy positions are and Lvl 3 essentially can detect all motion on the entire ship. You can get infrared vision, better bullets, a map of the ship, more battery life, waypoints pointing to objectives, faster download time of the datacores etc all upgrades have at least 3 more levels to them to improve them such as datacores being downloaded in 7.5 seconds to being download in just 1 second.

To assist you against the aliens the players can activate sentry guns and close off doors to prevent Alien from being able to easily move about the ship. Naturally the Aliens can destroy these doors but the time it takes them can mean the difference between life and death.

Once you have turned off the coolants to the reactor the Marines have 2 minutes to return to the shuttle.

This is a hardcore game you character will die in 1 hit from alien, turret, or fellow marine and once your character is dead so are all his upgrades. If your character gets close to an alien expect him to freak out with adrenaline. He will run quicker but his vision will also be impaired into a sort of tunnel vision. If you manage to complete a mission you carry on the character from the previous mission so you will start a new map with all of your upgrades on that character which will make the mission significantly easier on you and your teammates.

With procedurally generated maps of 3 different level styles, local coop, planned network multiplayer, and hordes of ravenous Aliens how can you go wrong? This is what a proper Aliens game should be and I am very excited to see what the developers will do with this game in the future.

10/10 buy if you are a fan Aliens or Space Hulk. This is what Colonial Marines should have been.

Placed into a world filled with Xenomorph scum, your sole objective is to collect data while surviving the alien onslaught. Space Beast Terror Fright does not have the latest greatest graphics or tries any fancy with the game mechanics. What it does have in abundance is fun. It's about as close to the old good alien games as we're going to get.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8rZPhnHc6pw
Each playthrough will be quite different given the games procedural nature, but you will always start as a marine on board a ship with a pulse rifle. Seeking out the DataCores rewards random perk unlocks for your character making them stronger and smarter while granting some chance of survival. One feature I enjoyed was the soundtrack also being somewhat procedural. Which basically meant all the alien fights were guaranteed to be that much more 'hollywood'.

Levels did contain sentries that could be enabled to setup choke points but careful management of doors seemed to be the best recipe for success. After finding all the DataCores you are then given the task of shutting down the main reactor, this is done in several stages and often resulted in a one final brutal showdown. Once the reactor is offline you will then have 90seconds to escape, succeed and you will be sent to yet another ship with bigger, badder aliens and more data to retrieve.

Price may seem a little high but personally I've not had this much fun shooting aliens for a while. With local co-op implemented now and online co-op planned for the future, can recommend keeping it shortlisted if the genre interests you. Cheers folks. :)

In early access with this game there is very little on offer, but even the idea itself isn't all that fantastic. You just shoot the same alien over and over with the help of numerous sentry guns. It's like someone took their favorite moments from the Aliens films and combined it with Warhammer 40k games like Space Hulk. You will die, a lot. Then you'll try again and die shortly after. Repeat this 50 times until you get bored with it.

Your main goal is to access datacores and set the self destruct for each randomly generated space station, but whether or not you accomplish this is largely up to luck. By luck I mean whether or not the game will cut you some slack and not be too cruel with enemy spawns and datacore placements. Datacore offer upgrades, but you're not given control over these and sometimes the game doesn't give them out at all. Also I hope you enjoy the machinegun they give you, because that's all you're getting.

Overall, this is a hit and miss game, like all randomly generated rogue-like games are. It has decent enough visuals and a nice atmosphere but the price is way too high for the little content you get. I do hope these guys add more stuff into the full version. An online co-op would be good, at the moment all you've got is local, which isn't all that great.

Space Beast Terror Fright is a game that lets you have an experience very similar to the movie Aliens. The weapon akin to the pulse rifle, the hundreds of xenomorphs, the music, the motion trackers, the sentry guns and their ammo count decreasing too fast, the overall look and feel, and so on. These Aliens elements are integrated to a roguelite skeleton, with a maze of corridors that change each time the player dies and then starts over.

I think that the atmosphere is really nailed perfectly, heavy and atmospheric when the monsters are not here, then intense and a lot more stressful when the xenomorphs are pouring down the corridors with no end in sight. Sentry guns to activate and doors to open/close add a layer of strategy to the shooting. The shooting is very divisive by the way... Invasive Heads Up Display, enormous weapon and its muzzle flash, huge recoil, screen shake... This is where you decide : are you willing to sacrifice slick shooting mechanics for immersion? This time, I say yes. The game is built around that in the first place: the corridors are small and the xenomorphs are huge targets going down in very few bullets. So killing is not difficult at all. However, the feeling of not seeing much and not being in control contributes to make the encounters even more stressful and the monsters more numerous and dangerous than they really are.
Well, except that sometimes there can really be TOO MUCH of them constantly attacking. There are holes in the ceilings that endlessly spawn more and more Aliens as you get closer to them, and some of these nests in the same location can cause some areas to be extremely difficult to get through.

Despite being in early access, Space Beast Terror Fright runs very well on my aging computer. The developers seem to listen to the community (without sacrificing their artistic integrity if possible, since complaints about each element of the immersive interface are bound to keep appearing) and they are set on adding features to the game (such as new monsters or online coop - local coop is already possible), which would be quite welcome. Indeed, the game as it is is an enjoyable and intense experience, but it remains too bare-bones to renew itself on the long term. I am really looking forward see this game grow and get new features, thanks to early access. However I enjoy playing the game as it is, I am satisfied by the experience already, with no unrealistic expectations on how different the game should become!
Edit: online coop was added! However the perfunctory netcode is based on P2P, and the game is only playing smoothly when there is very little lag between the players.

A game that truly feels like Aliens, with all the claustrophobia and hyperlethality of Space Hulk. The way the soundtrack automatically jumps and your FOV tunnelvisions when an alien appears in your field of view might initially seem cheap, but it's actually one of the most immersive ways I've seen a shooter implement a horror mechanic. The music also creeps up should an alien be creeping up on you, which is a godsend when you're too busy blasting away to glance down at your motion tracker and don't realize that a xenomorph's coming from behind. When you're done winding down from the adrenaline pump, having activated a sentry gun in a bottleneck and fled past the waves, there's a neat little snare drum rat-at-tat-tat that lets you know you're off the hook for at least the few seconds. The way your movement rate automatically goes from a sedate jog when all's quiet to a breakneck sprint for survival isn't just for effect or to add spookiness, it actively helps keep you alive when an alien suddenly bursts out from the breach you've got no choice but to brush past. All and all, it creates an extremely atmospheric experience that combines horror and gunplay in way that modern titles can't do with millions of dollars of budget.

There are some wonky things that can ruin seemingly good runs, though. While enemies can only spawn out of extremely obvious and visible breaches, they don't have any kind of animation that leaves them vulnerable. This means that you can be watching your (upgraded) motion tracker, see and hear zero blips anywhere near you, round a corner where there's a breach in the ceiling, and instantly die because an alien spawned right next to you. The solution to that of course is to never take even a fully upgraded motion tracker for granted, but it's still a tad frustrating. The sentry guns are actually relatively intelligent about friendly fire 99% of the time, refusing to shoot through you and instead giving a telltale klaxon to let you know that they have no shot, but since the bullets do have a marginal travel time, it is in fact possible to walk into the flight path of a bullet and (instantly) die. Also, reduced download time meshes poorly with a large battery and unupgraded recharge time, since currently you only recharge when actually downloading. Allowing you to interact with terminals purely to recharge your battery for just a few extra seconds here and there would be a nice touch.

The multiplayer is only splitscreen right now, which is an experience I wouldn't wish on anyone with all the obstrusive graphical elements included. (I'll admit that I have to remove all the graphical elements to have a hope of completing a level as I get used to the system and how dramatically my mouse sensitivity and movement can change on a dime.) Given the snap reflexes needed to Not Die in this game (a mere" 150ms is the difference between life and instant death)

I've only been at this thing for around 4 hours, but let me tell you, it feels like much, much longer. I already have a long, tragic, scrolling list of marines that tried and died on my menu, and each name I can remember as a different nightmare scenario.

Fraser had a great run. He'd picked up the motion sensor and penetrated deep into the heart of the ship, but stalled a bit activating a couple of turrets in adjacent rooms. Soon the aliens were swarming him from all sides, and low on ammo, he panicked and took a sentry bullet in the back.

Rodriguez couldn't decide which path he should take, and in his hesitation forgot to look behind him.

Winters upgraded his gear and charged forward confidently, but got lost in the maze of corridors. Alone and cornered, he fired his weapon dry before the end, dying in a pile of alien bodies and sulfurous smoke.

Pichot, oh Pichot. This brave woman fought her way through 24 datacores of hell, timing her movements and covering her approaches with well-placed sentry support. She made it all the way to the reactor, knuckles white and breath hot on  her helmet visor as she cautiously measured her ammo and battery life, never careless. By the end, though, the ship's computer wailed as the timer slowly counted down, and Pichot had lost her way battling through the corridors trying to reach the escape shuttle. She took many aliens with her before the final, merciful explosion.

It's moments like these with each new 'run' becoming their own story that make me love roguelike games. I read each name at the start of the round, imagine the character that's about to face this singularly terrifying mission, and charge headlong into the madness.

This sci-fi roguelike shooter has simple mechanics, but does more with them than many games for twice the price. The atmosphere in this game is perfect; claustrophobic, tense, urgent, terrifying, always pressing you to make those critical decisions. Should I move or wait? Activate this sentry or skip it in favor of speed? Left corridor or right? There's never a dull moment as you wonder what could wait for you around the corner.

The shooting itself may seem rudimentary, but the mechanics only add to the experience. A huge muzzle-flash and wafting smoke light up the dim interior of the ship as the aliens scream and charge you in waves. Your vision pulses with adrenaline and the tracker bleeps progressively louder warnings at you as you frantically maneuver. It takes some getting used to, but I found the mechanics fit the atmosphere nicely, and serve to compliment the gameplay if you learn how to work with them.

The aliens themselves charge at you in a wave, but this simple behavior doesn't hurt the game at all. The breaches are random, and the aliens can also bash down doors. Their numbers will continue to grow until they seem to be coming at you from every direction, and this keeps the game very tense and urges you to progress so you don't get surrounded.

The random generation of the maps one of the most interesting aspects to the game. It makes every playthrough seem unique and keeps the game very fresh, but on the downside, some runs can feel a bit easier than others. Sometimes you'll come into a level with a turret and four datacores right next to your starting position, and other times you'll have long, lonely corridors that stretch deep into the ship with no turrets and no datacores at all. The amount of cores you have to access changes as well, and I've seen numbers as low as 9 to as high as 24. These differences can make certain playthroughs feel much harder than others, but it's also great for replayability and helps each soldier have their own story. Some people just have an easier road in life, but can you beat the odds stacked against you and survive?

I'll be honest and say I really don't like supporting early access games. I've seen it burn too many people and normally will just wait until a game's release, but after reading the reviews and playing the demo of this game (yes, gasp, there's a demo!) I purchased it in early access immediately and have no regrets. It's a wonderful start to something I hope will grow and keep it's slimy, alien roots buried in what makes it so great and addictive.

I also haven't even beaten a single level, which hasn't changed my opinion of the game in the slightest, nor have I tried the co-op, which includes split screen with a friend on the same pc. This is a wonderful feature, if only I had any friends!

10/10 - I wish more early access games were this promising. If your at all a fan of the genre, or just well-made games in this age of AAA hype and bloated, million dollar failures, pick this one up. It's great and deserves the support!

For any developer considering making any action-horror game, the mechanics of this game are a goldmine. For any player who huffs at action-horror games, saying they can only consist of jump-scares and other fright-inducers that do nothing for atmosphere, the experience of this game is an eye-opener.

It's important to make the player have good (even great) items, for this kind of game. This is commonly done right: give the protagonist of the horror game an arsenal of over-the-top weapons that should (used correctly) destroy small armies singlehandedly.

What they get wrong is giving the player power in every other area. In this game you are denied:
Information (what you're up against exactly, how many there are, where they are, how overwhelmed you will be) via muzzleflash, darkness, mazelike locations, glitchy AI (seriously) and restrictive environments.
Movement (fight vs flight CHOICE, variety of approaches, etc) via no jumping, no control over speed of movement and confined spaces -- kudos to the developers for using the equivalent of clip brushes well here, by the way. I rarely get stuck on geometry.
Time (to prepare, to progress at your own pace of comfort, to even turn around) via endless consistent spawns, no way to block areas, no true safe zones, and a very large player hitbox (meaning that turning away from a nearby breach is instant death, you don't have TIME to look away).

Among other things. I can't really do a proper front-to-back-top-to-bottom breakdown of it, because there's so much going on here and I've no doubt the developers are sitting on a gold mine of ideas beyond what's on display.

But this is an -- perhaps THE -- important horror game. Even if it falls flat on so many levels (Quake/Quake 2-era model polycount, low texture quality, downsampling works oddly at best [obscuring the ammo counters on the weapon, really?] and seems a weird choice, very repetitive gameplay, no direction of character development, no character variety at start, limited player choice all around) it's damned good, and absolutely worth anyone's time.

I've only played singleplayer thus far, and this game oozes atmosphere in spades. It captures the isolation and tension of being stranded alone on a spaceship very well. Moreover, beneath the action is a layer of strategy for managing the alien swarm, that rewards thoughtful play, using doors and sentry guns to manage the flow of the alien swarm. Each stage can take up to 15 minutes (assuming you survive to the end), making it easy to have quick sessions.

Developer is actively updating the game, and each update so far has brought substantial improvements. I am still slightly concerned about the development roadmap, which I think lacks focus, but the developer seems to be making sound design decisions so far.

The game in its current state is very playable (heck, I thought the demo was great already) so there's no need to hang back just because it's in Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good Overall, would recommend.

For a game in Early Access this suffers from little that plague most early access titles. In its defense, it is very basic, you are a guy or gal with a gun, killing things that are trying to kill you. No crouch, jump, run, reload, or weapon juggling. The visuals aren't cutting edge, and don't have to be. The mood is effectively created, the lighting well rendered enough to tell darkness from shadow, and the score fits. Movement is smooth and fluid, game play is rather addicting, and the shooting is just as satisfying as the scares are terrifying.

Now why isn't it perfect? A few reasons. First, its a medium that would thrive with well coordinated multiplayer and the servers are dead. Second, the movement speed is a bit slow. The player could use a boost in forward motion, if not just adding the standard RUN function. Last, its hard as hell. Even on easy. If you like the challenge of wandering through endless tunnels with the nasties hot on your heels, completing objectives just seconds before it too late, then this is the one. If not, on easy with predictable maps it will take hours to grind out a strategy to get past the first level. Hours.

Overall I would rate this game very high, 7.5-8/10 and it has the possibility of going even higher.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is fun, intense, unique, and runs smoothly while still looking very good, masterfully utilizing the gritty sci-fi aesthetic. The way your visor HUD ties into the gameplay itself is elegantly done and adds to the player's immersion, which compliments the adrenaline-pumping claustrophobic feel the game is going for. It is fast-paced and hectic at times, but still has a strategical element to it, as you can open/close doors, activate defensive measures like lazers and automatic turrets, and so forth, which I imagine comes even more into play in multiplayer. That, however, leads me to my major gripe about the game: the difficulty is incredibly unfair in singleplayer. Now I'm no stranger to hard games, I enjoy an extra challenge, but as a lone marine you will often find yourself in situations where survival is next to impossible, even on the easier difficulty. Enemies spawn in endless numbers and with seemingly no pauses or waves once they really start coming. Seeing as all that bulky space marine armour of yours apparently does little good against ravenous aliens, a single attack by the bigger variant will take you down for good. It is simply not possible to cover all fronts at all times, leading to the outcome of your mission in singleplayer being more up to hoping for the game to generate a very linear level with lots of turrets and safe zones more so than the actual skill of the player. Talking about death, for me personally the game lacks an incentive to keep playing (and dying) over and over again, other than the sheer mayhem of slaughtering aliens. Most games with permadeath mechanics give you some sort of reward that carries over between playthroughs. Space Beast Terror Fright rewards you with a small selection of randomized upgrades that are only kept on successful missions, and completely reset on death. (And you will die a lot in singleplayer, as I've pointed out.) Now this might appeal to you, but for me, and some other players I imagine, the lack of any sort of progression whatsoever might be frustrating. A thing that's not really a genuine criticism of the game but just an odd design choice is that FOV distortion and muzzle flare are initially absolutely ridiculous. You're going to have to tune it way down in the settings to be able to see anything. I imagine this will be adjusted on full release. (Keys are also not rebindable as of now, but seeing as the controls are surprisingly simple and intuitive, this isn't really a problem.)

Overall Space Beast Terror Fright is a breath of fresh air in the FPS genre that is definitely worth experiencing, despite its issues.

This game.... is a scary game.

Regularly while playing you hear shrieks of terror over teamspeak when playing with friends, and mark my words. you want to use a voice program. because SBTF leaves you no time to type anything out.

The game has 1-4 players working to destroy an infested space ship or facility, (its got no story so whatever) anyway, so you arrive in your escape pod and move into a series of dark corridoors and rooms, you then try and gather all the datacores and activate the self destruct.
While thats happening, the aliens start breaching into sections of the ship, you try and fight them off while completing objectives.
You can seal breaches and hold the aliens up for a while in certain parts of a map or just use your guns to keep them at bay. this is really up to your map generation settings.
You generate a random map to play on, you can define a seed which lets you see what you are facing or go in blind, you can enable or disable various defensive objects, change the difficulty and even change the level a little using for example, the bigger rooms option.

So, it becomes a crazy hard game of 4 against the swarm when playing with friends or a horrifyingly jumpscare ridden fight for your life in solo.

The games got quite a few interesting features BUT. and heres the sad bit. the games got some issues.

Multiplayer:
the game uses peer to peer multiplayer but because of the way the game handles it... well. its got all the weaknesses and none of the strengths of peer to peer. if a player leaves your game, lags out or gets disconnected, the entire group becomes desynched and the game will either crash or not finish properly, often resulting in odd in game behaviour.
Because all 4 players in a 4 player match are considered server hosts, if one drops out the whole thing falls apart.
Also the game has no drop in ability meaning people must wait to join your group, this means its much harder to find a game to play in as you have to wait until someone is finished to join.
the ability to join and spectate while waiting is sorely needed.

User interface:
the user interface is horrible, and uses no standard conventions, its like someoene just threw together things and didn't think about how to present them usefully.
Changing loadouts after a mission requires clicking on buttons that are named oddly and navigation through menus and settings is just odd.
-Hopefully being early access this will get an update pass at somepoint

Weapons:
lets face it the weapons are workable but some of them are just plain useless without the right ammo. you also have a dupplicated weapon which is just a re-colored copy of another one and it fires powerful shots but so slow that your dead before you get a shot off making it pretty useless unless we get more powerful aliens at some point.

That being said. I like the game, its an old fashion shoot fest which is scary as hell and great fun in a group. its let down a little by the user interface and lack of different mission objectives but they don't stop the game from being fun. and as long as your internet connection is good, you should'nt encounter the most annoying problem with the game.
